            },
            "headline": "This baby is in the pursuit of happiness. Are South Korea\u2019s climate goals stopping him?",
            "description": "Tomorrow\u2019s hearing follows successful examples in Europe, and campaigners hope it will lead to more climate litigation in Asia.",
            "articleBody": "A one-year-old baby is a litigant in a case against the South Korean government over its \u2018insufficient\u2019 response to climate change. \u201cWoodpecker\u201d, as the baby boy is nicknamed, was not yet born when his parents filed the case on his behalf, alongside the parents of more than 61 children under the age of five. The young peoples\u2019 case was merged with three similar ones filed between 2020 and 2023, with the first hearing held in the  South Korean  constitutional court last month. The second and final hearing takes place tomorrow (21 May). Woodpecker isn\u2019t only one of the youngest plaintiffs in  climate litigation  history; this is the first case in East Asia to challenge national climate policies, and so could set a huge precedent. Why are South Koreans suing their government over climate change? Around 200 South Koreans from the combined cases are suing the government in total, claiming that its climate goals are too weak. Under its current nationally determined contribution (NDC) to meeting the UN Paris Agreement, the government is aiming to lower the country\u2019s greenhouse gas emissions (GHGs) to 40 per cent below 2018 levels by 2030. The Paris Agreement seeks to limit global heating to  1.5C  above pre-industrial levels, with an upper limit of 2C. But if all countries held South Korea\u2019s level of ambition, the world would shoot up to 3C by the end of the century, according to the  Climate Action Tracker .  The plaintiffs claim that the government is failing to provide constitutionally required protection of their fundamental rights. Namely: right to life, right to pursue happiness, right to general freedom, right to property, right to healthy environment. They also argue that the State is failing to fulfil its obligation to provide its people with protection from disasters. \u201cThe climate crisis is already upon us but the effects will be felt even more intensely by future generations. Cases like this are vital to safeguarding citizen\u2019s rights,\u201d says Jiyoun Yoo, Amnesty International Korea\u2019s Climate Justice Campaigner. \u201cTaking  legal action  against a state is often a long and arduous process which requires patience and perseverance and the courage of these pioneering plaintiffs is to be admired and applauded.\u201d With countries due to update their NDCs next year, the climate campaigners are hoping the case will force South Korea to be more ambitious in its next round of climate plans, lasting until 2035. Does South Korea\u2019s case draw on European climate lawsuits? East Asia may not have had a constitutional climate case like this before, but a growing tide of global climate cases provides plenty of examples to draw on.  Europe, Canada, Australia, India and Brazil have all seen similar cases filed in recent years, an article in the journal \u2018Nature\u2019 notes. Dr Mingzhe Zhu, a lecturer at the University of Glasgow, UK who explores the transformations of law in pursuit of a more sustainable future, sees a parallel between the South Korean case and Neubauer, et al. v Germany.  In this 2020 case, another group of young people filed a legal challenge to  Germany \u2019s Federal Climate Protection Act (Bundesklimaschutzgesetz or KSG) in the Federal Constitutional Court. They also argued that the KSG\u2019s goal of reducing GHGs by 55 per cent until 2030 from 1990 levels was insufficient, and so violated their human rights as shrined in Germany\u2019s constitution.  The Court accepted the intergenerational injustice thrust of their argument. It found that the KSG did not fairly distribute the carbon budget between current and future generations.  \u201cOne generation must not be allowed to consume large portions of the CO2 budget while bearing a relatively minor share of the reduction effort, if this would involve leaving subsequent generations with a drastic reduction burden and expose their lives to serious losses of freedom,\u201d it wrote. The outcome was that Germany\u2019s federal lawmakers made the KSG more ambitious in 2021, to target a 65 per cent cut in GHGs by 2030.  \u201cI would love to see if the Korean constitutional justices consider the Neubauer case and how they appreciate the interests of future generations,\u201d Dr Zhu tells Euronews Green. In Europe, a  landmark ruling  from the European Court of Human Rights (ECtHR) last month is inspiring for a couple of reasons, he adds. The Court ruled in favour of KlimaSeniorinnen (Swiss Elders for Climate Protection), a group of 2,000 Swiss women who argued they are particularly affected by their government\u2019s lack of climate action. \u201cThe applicants' strategy is clever because they manage to narrow the adverse climate impacts down to a specific group of victims,\u201d Dr Zhu says.  \u201cAlso, the ECtHR adopted the provisions of the ECHR [European Convention on Human Rights] to the needs for climate governance by using interpretative methods. I think both litigants and judges in East Asia (and other jurisdictions) will learn from this case as a whole, not only its ruling.\u201d What impact could the case have in South Korea and beyond? If the South Korean case is similarly successful, climate campaigners hope it will have big reverberations too. \u201cIf we have a favourable precedent in South Korea, I think that will really be a trigger in spreading this trend,\u201d Sejong Youn, who is a legal counsel for the case in  Seoul , told \u2018Nature\u2019. \u201cIt will send a message: all countries need to take action in order to tackle this global crisis, and there are no exceptions,\u201d he said. Litigation tends to be seen as a last resort in East Asian countries. But researchers say a successful outcome will embolden others in the region to act. \u201cEven if you lose this time, you can lose beautifully in the sense that you provoked social awareness,\u201d Dr Zhu told the journal. \u201cThe very fact that this case went to the constitutional court - that is already a certain sense of success.\u201d A decision on the case is expected later this year. ",

                            target="_blank"

      src="https://static.euronews.com/website/images/vector/social-icons/article-redesign-vk.svg" width="24" height="24" alt="vk"
             loading="lazy"       fetchpriority="low"      ><span>VK</span></span><img
      src="https://static.euronews.com/website/images/vector/social-icons/article-redesign-vk.svg" width="48" height="48" alt="vk"
       class="u-show-for-medium"       loading="lazy"       fetchpriority="low"      ></a></div></div></div></div><p class="c-article-summary">
        Tomorrow’s hearing follows successful examples in Europe, and campaigners hope it will lead to more climate litigation in Asia.
    </p><div class="c-article-content c-article-content--green js-article-content poool-content"><div class="c-article-content__first-element"></div><div class="c-ad c-ad-halfpage u-show-for-small-only"><div data-ad-id="adzone-halfpage_1" data-ad-type="halfpage" data-ad-position="1" class="c-ad__adzone advertising js-adzone"></div><div class="c-ad__placeholder"><img class="c-ad__placeholder__logo" src="https://static.euronews.com/website/images/logos/logo-euronews-180x22-grey-6.svg" width="180" height="22" alt="" loading="lazy"><span>ADVERTISEMENT</span></div></div><p>A one-year-old baby is a litigant in a case against the South Korean government over its ‘insufficient’ response to climate change.</p><p>“Woodpecker”, as the baby boy is nicknamed, was not yet born when his parents filed the case on his behalf, alongside the parents of more than 61 children under the age of five.</p><div class="c-ad c-ad-sticky-floor c-advertising-sticky-floor sales-advertising-sticky-floor u-hide-for-medium"><div data-ad-id="adzone-sticky-floor_1" data-ad-type="stickyFloor" data-ad-position="1" class="c-ad__adzone advertising js-adzone"></div><div class="c-ad__background"></div><button class="c-ad__btn-close" type="button" onclick="this.parentElement.classList.add('u-hide-for-all')"><img src="https://static.euronews.com/website/images/icons/icon-cross-10x10-grey-6.svg" width="10" height="10" alt="Close advertising" fetchpriority="high" loading="lazy"></button></div><p>The young peoples’ case was merged with three similar ones filed between 2020 and 2023, with the first hearing held in the <strong><a href="https://www.euronews.com/green/2024/01/09/south-korea-plans-to-ban-the-consumption-of-dog-meat-by-the-end-of-the-year">South Korean</a></strong> constitutional court last month. The second and final hearing takes place tomorrow (21 May).</p><p>Woodpecker isn’t only one of the youngest plaintiffs in <a href="https://www.euronews.com/green/2023/01/07/oatly-shell-and-coca-cola-why-are-climate-activists-taking-companies-to-court"><strong>climate litigation</strong></a> history; this is the first case in East Asia to challenge national climate policies, and so could set a huge precedent.</p><div data-stories-id="8447534,8444598" data-event="widget_related" class="widget widget--type-related widget--size-fullwidth widget--align-center"><div class="widget__wrapper"><div class="widget__ratio widget__ratio--auto"><div class="widget__contents"><ul class="widget__related_list"><li class="widget__related_listItem"><a href="https://www.euronews.com/green/2024/05/18/climate-activists-glue-themselves-to-munich-airport-runway">Climate activists glue themselves to Munich airport runway</a></li><li class="widget__related_listItem"><a href="https://www.euronews.com/green/2024/05/20/children-are-more-likely-to-be-hospitalised-for-asthma-during-heatwave-study-finds">Children are more likely to be hospitalised for asthma during heatwave, study finds</a></li></ul></div></div></div></div><h2>Why are South Koreans suing their government over climate change?</h2><p>Around 200 South Koreans from the combined cases are suing the government in total, claiming that its climate goals are too weak.  </p><p>Under its current nationally determined contribution (NDC) to meeting the UN Paris Agreement, the government is aiming to lower the country’s greenhouse gas emissions (GHGs) to 40 per cent below 2018 levels by 2030.</p><p>The Paris Agreement seeks to limit global heating to <a href="https://www.euronews.com/green/2024/02/08/alarmed-by-the-world-breaching-15c-for-a-year-heres-how-we-can-stop-it-being-permanent"><strong>1.5C</strong></a> above pre-industrial levels, with an upper limit of 2C. But if all countries held South Korea’s level of ambition, the world would shoot up to 3C by the end of the century, according to the <a href="https://climateactiontracker.org/countries/south-korea/"><strong>Climate Action Tracker</strong></a>.</p><div class="widget widget--type-image widget--size-fullwidth widget--animation-ease-in-up widget--align-center" data-ratio="0.5625"><div class="widget__wrapper"><div class="widget__ratio widget__ratio--auto"><div class="widget__contents"><figure class="widget__figure"><img class="widgetImage__image" loading="lazy" src="https://static.euronews.com/articles/stories/08/44/77/02/808x454_cmsv2_e5116ea3-0e91-53dc-99fa-b4492b08f2a2-8447702.jpg" alt="Climate activists carry Earth balloons during a rally demanding action in halting the climate crisis in Seoul, South Korea, September 2019." srcset="https://static.euronews.com/articles/stories/08/44/77/02/384x216_cmsv2_e5116ea3-0e91-53dc-99fa-b4492b08f2a2-8447702.jpg 384w, https://static.euronews.com/articles/stories/08/44/77/02/640x360_cmsv2_e5116ea3-0e91-53dc-99fa-b4492b08f2a2-8447702.jpg 640w, https://static.euronews.com/articles/stories/08/44/77/02/750x422_cmsv2_e5116ea3-0e91-53dc-99fa-b4492b08f2a2-8447702.jpg 750w, https://static.euronews.com/articles/stories/08/44/77/02/828x466_cmsv2_e5116ea3-0e91-53dc-99fa-b4492b08f2a2-8447702.jpg 828w, https://static.euronews.com/articles/stories/08/44/77/02/1080x608_cmsv2_e5116ea3-0e91-53dc-99fa-b4492b08f2a2-8447702.jpg 1080w, https://static.euronews.com/articles/stories/08/44/77/02/1200x675_cmsv2_e5116ea3-0e91-53dc-99fa-b4492b08f2a2-8447702.jpg 1200w, https://static.euronews.com/articles/stories/08/44/77/02/1920x1080_cmsv2_e5116ea3-0e91-53dc-99fa-b4492b08f2a2-8447702.jpg 1920w" sizes="(max-width: 768px) 95vw, (max-width: 1024px) 80vw, (max-width: 1280px) 55vw, 728px"><figcaption class="widget__caption"><span class="widget__captionWrap"><span class="widget__captionText">Climate activists carry Earth balloons during a rally demanding action in halting the climate crisis in Seoul, South Korea, September 2019.</span><span class="widget__captionCredit">AP Photo/Ahn Young-joon</span></span></figcaption></figure></div></div></div></div><p>The plaintiffs claim that the government is failing to provide constitutionally required protection of their fundamental rights. Namely: right to life, right to pursue happiness, right to general freedom, right to property, right to healthy environment. They also argue that the State is failing to fulfil its obligation to provide its people with protection from disasters.  </p><div data-ad-id="adzone-outstream_1" data-ad-type="outstream" data-ad-position="1" class="advertising advertising--no-label js-adzone outstream"></div><p>“The climate crisis is already upon us but the effects will be felt even more intensely by future generations. Cases like this are vital to safeguarding citizen’s rights,” says Jiyoun Yoo, Amnesty International Korea’s Climate Justice Campaigner.</p><p>“Taking <a href="https://www.euronews.com/green/2024/05/06/in-the-european-court-of-human-rights-we-won-a-victory-for-generations"><strong>legal action</strong></a> against a state is often a long and arduous process which requires patience and perseverance and the courage of these pioneering plaintiffs is to be admired and applauded.”</p><p>With countries due to update their NDCs next year, the climate campaigners are hoping the case will force South Korea to be more ambitious in its next round of climate plans, lasting until 2035.</p><div data-stories-id="6593974" data-event="widget_related" class="widget widget--type-related widget--size-fullwidth widget--align-center"><div class="widget__wrapper"><div class="widget__ratio widget__ratio--auto"><div class="widget__contents"><ul class="widget__related_list"><li class="widget__related_listItem"><a href="https://www.euronews.com/green/2022/04/07/my-anger-that-eight-children-had-to-fight-australia-in-court-for-two-years">Why I'm angry that eight children had to fight Australia in court for two years</a></li></ul></div></div></div></div><h2>Does South Korea’s case draw on European climate lawsuits?</h2><p>East Asia may not have had a constitutional climate case like this before, but a growing tide of global climate cases provides plenty of examples to draw on.</p><p>Europe, Canada, Australia, India and Brazil have all seen similar cases filed in recent years, an article in the journal ‘Nature’ notes.</p><div data-ad-id="adzone-native_1" data-ad-type="native" data-ad-position="1" class="advertising advertising--no-label advertising--native js-adzone"></div><p>Dr Mingzhe Zhu, a lecturer at the University of Glasgow, UK who explores the transformations of law in pursuit of a more sustainable future, sees a parallel between the South Korean case and Neubauer, et al. v Germany.</p><p>In this 2020 case, another group of young people filed a legal challenge to <a href="https://www.euronews.com/green/2022/05/20/climate-change-in-court-german-farmer-sues-volkswagen-over-high-emissions"><strong>Germany</strong></a>’s Federal Climate Protection Act (Bundesklimaschutzgesetz or KSG) in the Federal Constitutional Court. They also argued that the KSG’s goal of reducing GHGs by 55 per cent until 2030 from 1990 levels was insufficient, and so violated their human rights as shrined in Germany’s constitution.</p><p>The Court accepted the intergenerational injustice thrust of their argument. It found that the KSG did not fairly distribute the carbon budget between current and future generations.</p><p>“One generation must not be allowed to consume large portions of the CO2 budget while bearing a relatively minor share of the reduction effort, if this would involve leaving subsequent generations with a drastic reduction burden and expose their lives to serious losses of freedom,” it wrote.</p><p>The outcome was that Germany’s federal lawmakers made the KSG more ambitious in 2021, to target a 65 per cent cut in GHGs by 2030.</p><div class="c-ad c-ad-halfpage u-margin-bottom-3 u-show-for-small-only"><div data-ad-id="adzone-halfpage_2" data-ad-type="halfpage" data-ad-position="2" class="c-ad__adzone advertising js-adzone"></div><div class="c-ad__placeholder"><img class="c-ad__placeholder__logo" src="https://static.euronews.com/website/images/logos/logo-euronews-180x22-grey-6.svg" width="180" height="22" alt="" loading="lazy"><span>ADVERTISEMENT</span></div></div><div class="widget widget--type-quotation
    widget--size-fullwidth
    widget--align-center"><div class="widget__wrapper"><div class="widget__content"><blockquote class="widget__quote"><span class="widget__quoteText">I would love to see if the Korean constitutional justices consider the Neubauer case and how they appreciate the interests of future generations.</span></blockquote><cite class="widget__author"></cite></div></div></div><p>“I would love to see if the Korean constitutional justices consider the Neubauer case and how they appreciate the interests of future generations,” Dr Zhu tells Euronews Green.</p><p>In Europe, a <a href="https://www.euronews.com/green/2024/04/10/what-does-the-echrs-landmark-ruling-mean-for-human-rights-and-climate-change"><strong>landmark ruling</strong></a> from the European Court of Human Rights (ECtHR) last month is inspiring for a couple of reasons, he adds. The Court ruled in favour of KlimaSeniorinnen (Swiss Elders for Climate Protection), a group of 2,000 Swiss women who argued they are particularly affected by their government’s lack of climate action.</p><p>“The applicants' strategy is clever because they manage to narrow the adverse climate impacts down to a specific group of victims,” Dr Zhu says.</p><p>“Also, the ECtHR adopted the provisions of the ECHR [European Convention on Human Rights] to the needs for climate governance by using interpretative methods. I think both litigants and judges in East Asia (and other jurisdictions) will learn from this case as a whole, not only its ruling.”</p><div data-stories-id="8171602" data-event="widget_related" class="widget widget--type-related widget--size-fullwidth widget--align-center"><div class="widget__wrapper"><div class="widget__ratio widget__ratio--auto"><div class="widget__contents"><ul class="widget__related_list"><li class="widget__related_listItem"><a href="https://www.euronews.com/green/2024/05/15/positive-environmental-stories-from-2024">Renewable records and green awards: Positive environmental stories from 2024</a></li></ul></div></div></div></div><h2>What impact could the case have in South Korea and beyond?</h2><p>If the South Korean case is similarly successful, climate campaigners hope it will have big reverberations too.</p><div class="c-ad c-ad-halfpage u-margin-bottom-3 u-show-for-small-only"><div data-ad-id="adzone-halfpage_3" data-ad-type="halfpage" data-ad-position="3" class="c-ad__adzone advertising js-adzone"></div><div class="c-ad__placeholder"><img class="c-ad__placeholder__logo" src="https://static.euronews.com/website/images/logos/logo-euronews-180x22-grey-6.svg" width="180" height="22" alt="" loading="lazy"><span>ADVERTISEMENT</span></div></div><p>“If we have a favourable precedent in South Korea, I think that will really be a trigger in spreading this trend,” Sejong Youn, who is a legal counsel for the case in <a href="https://www.euronews.com/green/2024/01/10/its-time-to-rally-around-south-koreas-bold-stance-to-end-the-dog-meat-industry"><strong>Seoul</strong></a>, told ‘Nature’.</p><p>“It will send a message: all countries need to take action in order to tackle this global crisis, and there are no exceptions,” he said.</p><p>Litigation tends to be seen as a last resort in East Asian countries. But researchers say a successful outcome will embolden others in the region to act.</p><p>“Even if you lose this time, you can lose beautifully in the sense that you provoked social awareness,” Dr Zhu told the journal. “The very fact that this case went to the constitutional court - that is already a certain sense of success.”</p><p>A decision on the case is expected later this year.</p><div js-adzone"></div><div class="c-ad__placeholder"><img class="c-ad__placeholder__logo" src="https://static.euronews.com/website/images/logos/logo-euronews-180x22-grey-6.svg" width="180" height="22"
